DEB Stylized Fact: In unfavorable conditions, energy is primarily used for maintenance, not growth or reproduction.
Growth and reproduction rates highly depend on food availability and temperature, but modeled through the same basic parameters.
Nutrient assimilation follows a type II functional response (Monod or Holling function).
Temperature affects all reaction rates through Arrhenius relationship.
Acclimation changes DEB parameters systematically and predictably.
Seasonal variability affects energy allocation between growth, maintenance, and reproduction.
Nutritional quality of food affects assimilation efficiency and chemical composition of reserves.
Stress factors increase maintenance costs and reduce energy available for growth.
Photoperiod can act as a signal for changes in metabolic priorities.
Toxins affect DEB parameters through increased maintenance costs or reduced assimilation.
Oxygen availability limits metabolic rate and energy allocation efficiency in hypoxic environments.
pH changes affect metabolic enzyme function and energy conversion efficiency.
Salinity stress increases osmoregulation costs and reduces energy available for other functions.
